awd_titl_txt: RI: Small: Principles of Normative Multiagent Systems for Decentralized Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
Emerging technologies such as blockchain and the Internet of Things offer opportunities for multiple autonomous parties (people or organizations) to collaborate in new ways that respect everyone's interests.  This consideration applies as well to building software applications involving multiple agents, however our ways of building these software applications have not kept up with these opportunities.  Most current approaches focus on data and control from the unitary perspective of a single organization.  This project seeks to overcome two conceptual challenges in multiagent system design: over-constrained interactions that interfere with participants' autonomy, and the characterization of interactions in a manner that is not meaningful to humans.  This project, dubbed Mia, aims to enable innovative applications that promote users' autonomy with anticipated benefits in the quality of life for users as well as gains in efficiency for users and enterprises.  In particular, enabling decentralization without compromising on rigor could lead to new ways of realizing scientific and business interactions and thereby provide new pathways for value generation in society.  

This project seeks to support interoperation of autonomous parties for decentralized applications by investigating theoretical models and programming techniques for multiagent systems.  The Mia framework seeks to model interactions between autonomous parties via communication protocols that specify messages in support of fully decentralized enactments.  First, Mia will investigate ways to specify multiagent protocols such that a protocol can be effectively enacted by decentralized participants, each acting autonomously based on its local knowledge and private decision making, and one participant can verify the compliance of another participant with respect to the protocol.  Second, Mia will investigate how autonomous parties may achieve alignment on their joint activities through a formalization of norms modeled as directed deontic constructs.  Third, Mia will investigate ways in which to elicit stakeholder requirements that respects their autonomy; mine norms from logged interactions; and systematically induce flexible protocols from a model formulated in terms of norms.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
We live in a multiagent world. Our everyday interactions are highly decentralized. When we go see a physician, we interact with their front-office staff, with a nurse, possibly with a phlebotomist to have some blood drawn and a laboratory to evaluate those samples, with a pharmacy, and just about always with an insurance company and a payment service. When we have an HVAC unit installed at home, we may interact with an online shop (masking a complex supply network behind it), a shipper, an installer, a warranty company, a maintainer, and a repairer. These are just two of many settings where multiple autonomous parties must cooperate to produce societal value. 

 

Before the advent of computing, interactions between the concerned parties were naturally decentralized, reflecting their autonomy. Today, software (whether or not AI based) represents the concerned parties and interacts on their behalf. Unfortunately, current approaches largely sacrifice decentralization and give prominence to one or a few (effectively) central entities. A benefit of doing so is that a unified view of the data can simplify maintaining consistency. 

 

We would expect that successful coordination imposes some constraints on the interacting parties. However, current models and methods impose egregious constraints that unnecessarily restrict the flexibility of the interacting parties and thus hurt both their autonomy and their ability to deal with unexpected opportunities and challenges. 

 

The objective of this project was to investigate the right abstractions that can express the constraints necessary to satisfy stakeholder requirements but do not impinge upon the autonomy or flexibility of the participants any more than necessary. 

 

To this end, we developed an interaction-oriented foundation for multiagent systems and addressed the above limitations through novel and cohesive approaches. The attached diagram shows a multiagent system schematically, with two (of many) stakeholders interacting based on an interaction protocol, which specifies their interactions abstractly. Each stakeholder is represented by an agent. Each agent encodes its decision-making logic based on a representation of norms and events and communicates with other agents in accordance with the protocol using an enactment framework. The diagram identifies our three research thrusts: Enactment, Reasoning, and Specification.

 

Under Enactment, we developed groundbreaking methods for operational modeling, and related programming, of multiagent systems. Our interaction protocol languages are fully declarative and carry a formal semantics based on asynchronous communications. We produced tools to verify correctness of protocols. We also produced a series of programming frameworks that enable engineering multiagent systems by independently engineering their constituent agents. These approaches help produce multiagent systems of unmatched flexibility, as we demonstrated through an evaluation of leading other approaches.

 

Under Reasoning, we developed new models of social commitments and other deontic norms (roughly, formal abstractions for business contracts) and showed how to use these as a basis for accountability while respecting agent autonomy. By capturing the meaning of an interaction, our approach avoids the rigidity and complexity of traditional models. We implemented our approach over two blockchain implementations to show how the main limitation of blockchain (its confusion of social state and event data) can be resolved to enable autonomous agents while retaining a blockchain's benefit in providing a robust ledger functionality.

 

Under Specification, we showed how accountability can be used as a basis for specifying multiagent systems at a level that matters to stakeholders, and avoiding being swamped by low-level details. We developed natural language processing techniques to understand business contracts and arguments as a way to provide a basis for capturing stakeholder requirements. 

 

There are cross-connections between these thrusts. We have begun developing ways to reason about commitments as part of enactment to better facilitate collaboration. The relationship between specification techniques and formal models is apparent but we have not investigated it yet. 

 

We defer to future research the challenges of (1) developing AI agents based on cognitive models, (2) interaction protocols at abstractions higher than that of individual messages and taking into account joint actions, (3) organizational modeling to support composing multiple systems and whose membership and structure change dynamically. Each of these directions will take advantage of modern generative AI combining it with insights from this project in how agents can reason about others to achieve flexible cooperation. 

 

For broader impacts, we trained graduate researchers, incorporated results of this research into undergraduate and graduate courses, gave tutorials, and engaged with practitioners.

 

For intellectual merit, this project set out to investigate ways to support the interoperation of autonomous and heterogeneous interacting agents. These investigations have been highly successful in uncovering new scientific principles by which to construct decentralized multiagent systems.
